body:
Just checked:

* no problems with `statsmodels` 0.12.1, using the latest development version
* no problems with `statsmodels` 0.12.1, using the 0.8.0 release version

So it's probably also `statsmodels` related. I don't have a `statsmodels` 0.13.0 setup at hand currently, could someone try testing that?

rename.from: [BUG] AutoARIMA fit not working in sktime 0.8.0
rename.to: [BUG] AutoARIMA fit breaks with sktime 0.8.0, statsmodels 0.13.0

body: Downgrading to statsmodels 0.12.1 didn't fix the error for me, but downgrading to scikit-learn 0.24.2 fixed it.

oh, interesting! So we have a `scikit-learn` problem too now?
`scikit-learn` recently upgraded to 1.0.

We probably should really adopt defensive version bounds #1480 or `sktime` might randomly break when any of our core dependencies update.

issue.title: [MNT] adopt defensive upper version bounds on package dependencies

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
The `statsmodels` breakage has again shown us that under the current model, `sktime` is vulnerable to interface changes in other packages at version zero. See #1478.

Should we perhaps adopt a more defensive stance?

More precisely:

* upper version bounds for *all* dependencies
* at each release, we bump the upper bound to the current versions, or the highest versions that don't cause breakage
* if at a release we cannot move the upper bound to current version, we open a maintenance issue to log this

Opinions, @mloning, @aiwalter, @freddyaboulton?

body:
@asksteph, but this would mean it's actually a problem of `pmdarima`, since that's where the error is coming from?
(not `statsmodels` as I originally thought)

Would it be possible for you to try isolate the problem to `pmdarima`'s `auto_arima` (using `sklearn` 1.0) and if that's where it's from, post on the `pmdarima` GitHub and link the issue here?

On our side, I think we need to understand why the tests are not catching this, e.g., does it occur only in a combination of specific versions that you have? The call to `fit` should be covered by the tests, testing `fit` etc is one of our most important automated checks.

rename.from: [BUG] AutoARIMA fit breaks with sktime 0.8.0, sklearn 1.0, statsmodels 0.12.1 or 0.13.0
rename.to: [BUG] AutoARIMA fit breaks with sktime 0.8.0, sklearn 1.0, pmdarima 1.8.2

body:
👋🏻 

As a contributor from the `pmdarima` side, hopefully I can speak to the issue. We were utilizing `scikit-learn`'s [`if_delegate_has_method`](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.metaestimators.if_delegate_has_method.html). That function has since been [deprecated](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/20506) in favor of [`available_if`](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.utils.metaestimators.available_if.html?highlight=available_if#sklearn.utils.metaestimators.available_if). We had a [fix](https://github.com/alkaline-ml/pmdarima/pull/455) in place fairly quickly after `scikit-learn`'s 1.0 release that will use `if_delegate_has_method` on older versions of `scikit-learn` and `available_if` on newer versions. This fix is included in `pmdarima` [1.8.3](https://github.com/alkaline-ml/pmdarima/releases/tag/v1.8.3), but it does mean that `pmdarima` 1.8.2 and `scikit-learn` 1.0 are unfortunately incompatible.

It should also be noted that this is a [legit bug on the `scikit-learn` side](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/21144). The function may be deprecated, but it has not been removed. It is just bugged in 1.0.

Hello @aaronreidsmith! Thanks to you and @asksteph for tracking down the problem!

Based on this, I assume that a new, vanilla installation of `sktime` wouldn't suffer from this bug, since it would install the newest releases respectively?

Further, @aaronreidsmith, I would be interested to hear your opinion on devensive version bounds, see #1480. Is that a good thing, e.g., have upper bounds on everything and only increase them after testing new upper bounds? Or does it cause a lot of trouble if multiple packages in the dependency tree do this?
